title: Celtic’s Europa League clash with Lazio categorised as high-risk fixture but Neil Lennon looking forward to ‘glamour game’
text:
Celtic’s home tie against Lazio in the Europa League on Thursday evening has the potential to be a gala occasion for the Scottish champions – already top of Group E – but the occasion could also be a platform for racist behaviour of the sort which nearly forced England’s players to walk off during their recent Euro 2020 qualifier in Bulgaria.

The Parkhead fixture has been categorised as high-risk in security terms and the 1,500 Lazio fans who will be escorted to and from the stadium will also be monitored by a squad of Italian police who specialise in anti-Mafia and anti-terrorist operations.

Their concern is a hardcore of around 300 ultras with fascist sympathies and apprehension has been heightened because of racist behaviour in the group match against Rennes, which caused Uefa to close a section of the Stadio Olimpico for Celtic’s visit next month. As it happens, Thursday night's referee is Ivan Bebek of Croatia, who was in charge of the Bulgaria v England game, although Neil Lennon stressed that he wanted to accentuate the positive.

“I’m hoping tomorrow is a celebration of football between two great clubs. In the main I think Lazio have a great support,” said the Celtic manager. “There is always a minority who want to make noise for the wrong reasons or put a stain on the game.

“I’m hoping at the end of the game we’re talking about the great atmosphere for two great sides playing in a great game of football.”

Ryan Christie, the Celtic midfielder, added: “If racial abuse becomes a part of this game then it’s up to Uefa and the referees to make a decision. I’d obviously have no qualms about walking off the park.

“In this day and age, it’s probably going to need strong stances like that to really put a message across and try and stop it.”

On the field of play, Lennon hopes to see an end to Celtic’s poor record against Italian opposition. Although their greatest triumph was against Inter Milan in the 1967 European Cup final of 1967, the Hoops have won only four of another 24 ties.
